fields.description:
As a build engineer or developer, I'd like to be able to re-run a job within a plan.  If my infrastructure fails me I don't want to have to re-run a multi-stage project.  

I don't know how you would assign a build number.  It would have to have an additional suffix so that it doesn't collide with the concurrency feature or if the plan kicked off another run.
fields.summary: Ability to re-run a job within a plan without having to run the entire plan again

fields.description:
Currently the attribute *name* contains concatenated "project name - plan name - job name" which is usually very long. I would suggest to add another attribute e.g. *short-name*. 
The same is for job key.

Example:
<plan enabled="true" type="job" name="Jira 4.2 Release Branch - 4.2 Plugins - External Importer Func Tests" key="JIRA42-PLUG-EXTIMPFUNC">
fields.summary: Add short name of job to the /rest/api/latest/plan/PLAN?expand=stages.stage.plans

fields.description:
In our bamboo deployment, we have multiple remote agents running on the same machine. Each of them must be installed and configured separately, and if a job can run on all the agents, there will be one build directory per agent, and the incremental build won't be optimal.

Being able to install one "remote agent server" and configure agents on it like local agents on the server would simplify our setting.
fields.summary: Allow a remote agent to take more than one job at a time

fields.description:
Currently, users have to edit {{bamboo.cfg.xml}} file and restart Bamboo to configure the Broker URI.

Agent connectivity issues are sometimes caused due to the Broker URI being incorrect, and its tedious to edit the cfg.xml file and restart Bamboo.
fields.summary: Make Bamboo Broker URI configurable via General Config page

fields.description:
Krystian:
In the history of Bamboo we had several versions which were required to be used to upgrade to the newer version. Ie. to upgrade from Bamboo 1.0 to Bamboo 2.1 you need to execute upgrades to 1.1.2, 1.2 and 2.0.
The latest of this "milestone-upgrade" versions is 2.0. This is why I propose to drop all the upgrade tasks which were introduced by pre-2.0 versions. The main benefit would be dropping the last usages of old and usually deprecated APIs
According to https://extranet.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=636158922 it means all pre 801 upgrade tasks (18 of them)

Przemek:
+ make it impossible to use new Bamboo version to upgrade from build number of pre-2.0.x version.
That check should have been included in 2.0.x anyway...

Marek:
+1, those upgrade tasks are in sources too long. For historical stuff we got subversion

Anton:
Yes, if we do this, Bamboo *must* lockup upon starting if it detects that it is being brought up against a version which is before 2.0.
We should also stop the user importing XML backups from pre 2.0 versions.
In all these cases the user should be given a very clear error message and no data should be changed.
Can I ask why do you bring this up now? What caused you to do this? If we do this, will this simplify some other work we need to do for 3.0?
How long will the work of stopping a pre 2.0 upgrade/import take?

Krystian:
Adding protection against upgrade/import from pre-2.0 version is rather simple and would require ~4h of work (including testing).
I'm bringing this now cause last week Przemek has spotted a small bug which was caused by internal use of deprecated API (BuildManager). I thought that releasing 3.0 is a good moment to drop this (and maybe other) legacy APIs which were deprecated in 2.7 and previous versions.
A lot of uses of deprecated API is buried in old upgrade tasks which led to idea I presented in my original email.
This will probably not simplify other work for 3.0 but has a potential to help us find forgotten usages of legacy code that should have been updated some time ago.
fields.summary: Remove pre-2.0 upgrade tasks and provide protection against upgrade from pre 2.0 version

fields.description:
Hi, we created an elastic agent with the capability "elastic = true" and surprisingly, the job that requires that capability puts in the UI: "Matching agents=0"

Until friday the agent didn't pick up the job. Fortunately today (new version  3.0-i1 build 2204) it seems that the job is running, but the message is still there.

The logs doesn't seem to show any additional information.
fields.summary: Decorate Current Requirements table for Job configuration to highlight unmet capabilities

fields.description:
The build screens used by the Confluence and Studio dev teams display the following information:

* the status of the plan (passed, failed)
* whether the plan is running or queued
* whether the plan is enabled.

We have to retrieve two separate REST resources to determine this information, and can't currently determine whether a build is queued or not:

* [/rest/api/latest/result/RELENG-TRUNKSRCDISTRO16/latest|https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/rest/api/latest/result/RELENG-TRUNKSRCDISTRO16/latest] - for the last build result
* [/rest/api/latest/plan/RELENG-TRUNKSRCDISTRO16|https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/rest/api/latest/plan/RELENG-TRUNKSRCDISTRO16] - for whether the build is running or not.

It would be great if there was a single REST resource that gave us the consolidated information. 

I think a good fix would be to make some additions to the {{/plan}} resource:

* include the last completed build result as an expandable child
* include the state (passed/failed) of the last completed build on that element, even when not expanded
* include whether the plan has any queued builds, in addition to whether it is currently building.
fields.summary: Single REST resource for plan + latest build result information

fields.description:
When you start a fresh bamboo instance, if you dont have any builders set up, you can't create a plan straight away.
The dialog gives you the capability to add a builder but this may not be the way you want to go. If you plan on using EC2 you need to enable it, and it will create builders for you.  

No where does Bamboo indicate that enabling EC2 will populate those builders/jdks for you.
fields.summary: Clean Bamboo instance should indicate ec2 will provide builders

fields.description:
This would be useful for:
* Code Repository paths
* File system location to checkout code into (work directory)
* File system location for the Home Directory (backups/ProjectDir/etc and other paths defined in the bamboo.cfg.xml).

Currently, possible solutions are:
* To map the external disk in a local driver
* To use the file protocol file:////someserver/folder (four slashes)
fields.summary: Support UNC Paths

fields.description:
I've found some error messages in Tardigrade logs about build failures of builds that seemed to be completed just fine.

Following that, I've found that BuildManager is still used in some places in Bamboo, causing problems with some of the functionality. For example, BuildCompletedEventListener operates on Buildables but uses BuildManager for build key validation.
This which never works, since valid job keys are not valid build keys - effectively disabling the BuildCompleted plugins.

There are not that many places that use BuildManager, about half of them are old UpgradeTasks. This should be fixed, and potentially backported to 2.7 too (since it breaks plugins in a way that cannot be fixed by developers).
fields.summary: BuildManager still used in core Bamboo functionality

fields.description:

2010-12-11 00:55:08,857 ERROR [http-8085-3] [ArtifactDownloadStrategy] Failed to read : /opt/dogfood/panda/home/artifacts/SANDBOX-STB/JOB1/build-00158/Elastic/bamboo-elastic-agent-2.7.3.zip
ClientAbortException:  java.net.SocketException: Broken pipe
        at org.apache.catalina.connector.OutputBuffer.realWriteBytes(OutputBuffer.java:358)
        at org.apache.tomcat.util.buf.ByteChunk.append(ByteChunk.java:325)
        at org.apache.catalina.connector.OutputBuffer.writeBytes(OutputBuffer.java:381)
        at org.apache.catalina.connector.OutputBuffer.write(OutputBuffer.java:370)
        at org.apache.catalina.connector.CoyoteOutputStream.write(CoyoteOutputStream.java:89)
{code}

Fortunately, it only meant that the user has canceled the artifact download. We should not log output exceptions as an error (and the stack trace is unnecessary of course).

fields.summary: Bamboo 2.7.X is not considering BuildState 'Pending' during import

fields.description:
ensure it does!
* remote agent
* elastic one
fields.summary: Git Repository should work on remote agents

fields.description: So they are shared between plans and consume less storage on bamboo server.
fields.summary: Git repository should cache the same repositories on bamboo server.
Git Repository should detect code changes on remote repository
Git repository should display changesets after change detection.

fields.description: It also is able to fetch further changesets into existing git repository on agent.
fields.summary: Git repository is able to checkout code from master branches.

fields.description:
Like in other repositories - if something fail during code checkout/fetch then Git repository should try to recover - in worst case remove working directory and clone remote repository from scratch.

P.S. watch out for lock files in .git directory (they lock 'checkout' operation) - teamcity had problem with that too AFAIK.
fields.summary: Git repository should recover from failures during checkout.

fields.description:
Instead of showing 10 753 changeset.
See: [http://groups.google.com/group/bamboogitplugin/browse_thread/thread/532384d62f62a930#]
Git Repository should behave as other (CVS/SVN) repositories with regard to first build.
fields.summary: Initial Git build should ignore history in 'changes' tab.

fields.description:
Currently we use full clones during:
* collecting changes, on bamboo server
* code retrieval, on agents, during performing build

In both cases we don't need the whole history, so if it is possible we should do shallow clones. 

Shallow clones are not implemented in JGit yet.

Also - both server and agents should be able to fetch afterwards properly. Corner test case:
* detecting new rev A -> add to queue
* detecting new rev B (grandchild of A) -> add to queue (concurrent builds are on)
* agent -> takes rev B, does shallow clone on it (so it won't have rev A)
* agent -> takes rev A, does fetch - in such case agent should somehow obtain rev A
fields.summary: Git repo should use shallow clones instead of full clones.

fields.description: I was testing Git on 'master' branch. I should test if it work on other branches as well. Probably this works already. However we need to write up some tests.
fields.summary: Git Repository should properly detect code has changed on arbitrary branch

The *Overwrite Existing Data* from the DB Setup installation step is not being completely effective. Data is not deleted and after the Admin User Creation step, the installation process fails when it tries to create DB entries that already exist.

It should also be tested with other DBs (not only MySQL).

fields.description: Provide the ability to cancel a build trigger and hence the build will not run.
fields.summary: Provide plugin point allowing cancelling of the build trigger

fields.description:
The code changes in subversion should be listed sorted by path and file name.

For instance, if Alice has made changes to file A/foo.c, A/foo.h, and B/bar.c, and in the same build, Bob has made changes to B/baz.h, B/baz.c, and C/quux.h, then Bamboo often lists the changes like this:

{quote}
* Alice
Some change comment
** A/foo.c (version 42)
** B/bar.c (version 42)
** A/foo.h (version 42)
* Bob
I have made a change
** B/baz.h (version 43)
** C/quux.h (version 43)
** B/baz.c (version 43)
{quote}

Especially with commits that change many files, quickly looking for a particular file or directory in this list becomes almost impossible. A sorted list like the following would help:

{quote}
* Alice
Some change comment
** A/foo.c (version 42)
** A/foo.h (version 42)
** B/bar.c (version 42)
* Bob
I have made a change
** B/baz.c (version 43)
** B/baz.h (version 43)
** C/quux.h (version 43)
{quote}
fields.summary: Sort changed files

fields.description:
Currently stage/job creation and manipulation permissions are slightly inconsistent.  And what is made available in the UI does not match the actual capabilities of that user.        
      
The Way It Should Work:

|| ACTION || CHAIN || STAGE || JOB |
| Creation | GLOBAL_CREATE | CHAIN_ADMIN | GLOBAL_CREATE \\ & CHAIN_ADMIN|
| Deletion | CHAIN_ADMIN | CHAIN_ADMIN | CHAIN_ADMIN |
| Edit | CHAIN_EDIT | Details - CHAIN_EDIT \\ Rearranging Stages/Jobs - CHAIN_ADMIN | CHAIN_EDIT |

Other:
Disabling Protected By Build.
Editing stage information protected by edit, however if easier also protected by Chain Admin.

fields.description:
I got this error message:
bq. Could not find the 1'th build for build JIRA HEAD - TPM LDAP - TPM Active Directory

There is no cardinal "1th" nor "2th" or even "3th".
(And the apostrophe is weird too).
It should be 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th, ..., 10th, 11th, 12th, 13th, ... , 20th, 21st, 22nd, 23rd etc.
Which is all probably way too much work to be bothered with such an unimportant message.
Not sure if Bamboo is i18n-able, but this is even more of a headache if you want to be able to translate to other languages.

I would suggest you avoid the problem altogether by a rewrite to something like: "Could not find build 1 for build JIRA HEAD - TPM LDAP - TPM Active Directory"
fields.summary: Bad English in Error message

fields.description: Bamboo doesn't have permissions for who can execute a build on an agent - we should have Permissions for who can trigger a manual build on an agent.
fields.summary: Agent permissions based on user/group membership

fields.summary: Get rid of vcsversion-plugin

fields.description:
Where should you get taken when moving between plan and job within the configuration pages.  Currently it works like this
1) if there is an equivalent tab take you to that tab
2) when moving to the chain (with no equiv) it takes you to the stages tab
3) when moving to the job (with no equiv) it take you to whatever tab you have saved in the cookie

Alternatives
* Replace #3 always taking you to the builder tab of the job. 
* Replace #2 and #3 to take you to the plan/job details page.
* Replace #2 to also take you to the cookied page.
* Replace #1 and #2 to always take you to the cookied page.
fields.summary: Confirm/Fix Plan Navigation For Configuration

fields.description:
I've been trying out the Artifactory Bamboo plugin.
The plugin currently fails with a null pointer exception caused by ManualBuildTriggerReason.getUserName() returning null.

I've filed a bug report and suggested workaround at JFrog, but I think the root cause is probably a Bamboo bug.
https://issues.jfrog.org/jira/browse/BAP-26



http://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo/2.7/com/atlassian/bamboo/v2/build/trigger/ManualBuildTriggerReason.html#getUserName()
fields.summary: ManualBuildTriggerReason.getUserName() returns null.

fields.description:
Looking at the chain result, i see all jobs in queue.  I click stop on the chain result.  All but two of the jobs were stopped the other two were left to run. They immediately started running.  This is on tardigrade.

Is it possible that the builds were caught in a weird state between queued and being picked up, and this cause the stop to not work.  Or perhaps there is another reason.  

I have had other intermittent problems with stopping chains lately, but I am never sure what I was doing so dont have enough info to put in a bug report.  Essentially i click stop and the jobs dont stop.
fields.summary: Stopping a chain did not stop all jobs
